ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: The value of the course depends almost entirely on the client project -- my group's was disappointing, with little learned from the client.

10 and 11: Maureen doesn't value student feedback. Her attitude is very much "this is my decision." That's more acceptable in a curriculum based course, but not a capstone. Instructor doesn't require enough from clients. She clearly has favorite clients and speakers and just has the same curriculum and clients every year. It's very obvious how stale the course is. I do not believe the instructor has enough relevant experience or higher education to be the sole instructor of a capstone and client based course.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Good to get a chance to sit in front of a client.
My group had to be very pro-active in terms of how we structured the project and moved forward with it -- as is often the case in the working world.
Having a professional experience while at school and dealing with real life projects and clients.
The opportunity to work with a client that will (hopefully) use some of the info you gather. More practice presenting well and writing readable summaries.
The class provides a practical experience into consulting. The learning and satisfaction are highly related to the actual client and project work.
Experience with client engagement

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Client selection could be dramatically improved - several projects were unrealistically scoped. Grading and evaluation method is in serious need of modernization - "reading ease" is a simplistic and inappropriate metric for the precision (and concision) required of good consulting deliverables. Admission into the class should either be more selective, or completely open, with expectations set with clients that they may get consultants with no relevant expertise in the area of their project (and expectations set that students with relevant skills will be expected to carry their teams).

The guest lectures weren't coherent, and in some cases the presenters weren't well prepared. They were not very useful at all. Maureen clearly has favorite clients, who frankly, aren't that good at presenting.
Vetting client projects. I would have liked if the client had been forced to write a few deliverables upfront, as well as disclose more about what information was available.
Curating meaningful projects

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I wanted to gain greater familiarity with utilities, and this project enabled that.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Work on project management and client management.
The client fit well with my interest in utilities and the solar market. Also, the course can serve as a capstone.
I wanted to produce a deliverable that I could add to my resume. I don't think I have that.
Interested in client-based consulting
I wanted more consulting experience, particularly with a private company.
I wanted to gain experience in environmental business consulting.
Capstone class, client engagement

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: No -- I wanted to learn more about how the client firm operates, but the client was largely passive over the course of the semester.
No. This was like a poorly executed internship.
No
Yes
Yes, although the relationship with the client was weak, so that aspect could have been better.
Definitely, in the term of getting consulting experience. Somewhat less so, in terms of the specifics of quantitative skills.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Advantages -- we each came to the group with different strengths that allowed us to learn from each other.
Learning your own strengths and leadership skills.

The advantages were that work was done much more efficiently, and multiple points of view combined. The disadvantages were that I did less of a "deep dive" than I normally would do, since the group decided against specific recommendations.
Advantages: learning how to work in teams Disadvantages: differences in ability and engagement in project work

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Review the list of clients carefully before committing to a project.
If you don't get the client you want, drop the class. It's not worth it.
Give feedback to teammates early and often
